column1: === European exploration ===
The explorers Hume and Hovell arrived at what their maps called 'Crossing Point'
column2: but is now known as the Murray River at Albury
column3: on 16 November 1824. They named the river the Hume River
column4: after Hume's father
column5: and the next day inscribed a tree by the river bank before continuing their journey south to Westernport in Victoria. In 1830
column6: explorer Captain Charles Sturt discovered the Hume River downstream at its junction with the Murrumbidgee River. Not realising it was the same river
column7: he named it the Murray River. Both names persisted for some time
column8: Hume falling into disuse eventually in favour of Murray. The Aboriginal name for the river was Millewa. A crossing place for the Murray became popular close to where Hovell inscribed the tree. In summer it was usually possible to cross the river by foot.

column1: === European settlement ===
Among the first squatters to follow in the steps of the explorers and settle in the district were William Wyse and Charles Ebden.

The first European buildings erected at the crossing place were a provisions store and some small huts. A survey for a town was commissioned in 1838 by Assistant Surveyor Thomas Townsend who mapped out Wodonga Place (the present Wodonga Place) as the western boundary
column2: Hume Street as the northern boundary
column3: Kiewa Street to the east and Nurigong Street to the south
column4: with Townsend Street being the only other north–south road
column5: and Ebden and Hovell Streets being the two other east–west roads. Townsend proposed the settlement be named 'Bungambrewatha'
column6: the Aboriginal name for the area
column7: but when his plan was eventually approved and published in the Government Gazette on 13 April 1839 the name had been changed to Albury.Albury is said to be named after a village in Kent

column1: === Lake Hume ===
Lake Hume is situated on the Murray River 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) upstream of Albury. The Hume Dam (colloquially termed the Weir locally) wall construction took 17 years
column2: from 1919 to 1936. A hydro-electric power plant supplies 60 MW of power to the state grid. When full
column3: the lake covers 80 square kilometres (31 sq mi).

column1: The lake was created for irrigation purposes and has caused significant changes to the flow patterns and ecology of the Murray River. Before the construction of the Hume Weir
column2: flows in normal (non-drought) years were low in summer and autumn (though still significant overall)
column3: rising in winter due to seasonal rainfall and reaching a flood-peak in late spring due to snow-melt in the Murray and its tributaries' alpine headwaters. The flow is now effectively reversed
column4: with low flows in winter and sustained
column5: relatively high flows in late spring
column6: summer and early autumn to meet irrigation demands
column7: although the spring flood peak has been virtually eliminated. The water released from the base of the Hume Weir is unnaturally cold
column8: at least 10 °C (18 °F) colder than it naturally should be. This flow reversal
column10: and removal of the spring flood peak
column11: has led to the drying out and loss of many billabongs and has harmed the populations of native fish of the Murray River such as the iconic Murray Cod.

column1: === Rail ===
Albury railway station is on the main Sydney-Melbourne railway line. Originally
column2: New South Wales and Victoria had different track gauges
column3: which meant that all travellers in either direction had to change trains at Albury. To accommodate this
column4: a very long railway platform was needed; the 450-metre (1
column5: 480 ft) long covered platform is one of the longest in Australia. The broad gauge section of track between Seymour and Albury has now been converted to standard gauge; there is no longer a break-of-gauge at Albury station. The station is served by a three daily V/Line train services from Melbourne (terminating at Albury) and the NSW TrainLink Melbourne-Sydney XPT service
column6: which runs twice daily in each direction.

column2: the 5-foot-3-inch (1.60 m) broad gauge railway line from Melbourne reached the township of Belvoir/Wodonga. In 1881
column3: the New South Wales 4-foot-8.5-inch (1.435 m) standard gauge railway line reached Albury
